Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Remaking Toxicity: Computational Toxicology and Urban Exposure Experiences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Introduction

This doctoral dissertation improvement grant will support an ethnographic study that focuses on toxicologists at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency who are developing new toxicity testing methods and on people living with chronic exposures in a low-income minority community in Phoenix, Arizona. The project will use data collected from participant observation, ethnographic interviewing, and scientific and community documents to identify the ways in which current chemical knowledge practices differ from prior practices and to analyze the socio-political implications of these changes.

Intellectual Merit

This project will serve to enhance the literature on co-production and distributed knowledge systems, as well as contemporary debates about the distinction between the environment, the body, the self, and technology. It will provide additional perspectives on how scale is understood in environmental justice contexts by investigating temporal and biological scales of toxicity, thereby complementing the use of spatial scales. It will also improve understandings of exposure experiences in disadvantaged communities where environmental justice activism is not prominent and exposures are complex. By engaging expert and lay notions of toxicity as they evolve, the research findings will be generalizable to broader questions about the relationship between science and public knowledge in an era where the growth and dissemination of knowledge proceeds at an increasingly rapid pace.

Broader Impacts

Research results will contribute to debates about the desirability of various types of knowledge about complex chemical risks. They will help to understand how environmental health and safety should be protected. They will inform interactions between scientific and lay knowledge practices, site remediation, and policy making in the United States. They may also serve to orient toxicologists and regulators to environmental justice issues and to publics who deal most intimately with chemical substances. Results will be disseminated through presentations to each study community and to broader scholarly communities, in a white paper written for the EPA?s National Environmental Justice Advisory Council, and through activities developed for an environmental outreach program in the urban field site.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the United States today, mainstream discourse about chemicals tends to emphasize their pervasiveness in the lives and bodies of all Americans. But chemical harm also accrues in dispersed and disparate ways. The research supported by this award analyzes the politics of chemical knowledge production and experiences of chemical harm under these dueling conditions of ubiquity and unevenness. These dynamics are considered specifically through ethnographic research with federal research scientists developing methods to populate data gaps about thousands of chemicals circulating in commerce and with members of low-income, minority communities who are particularly vulnerable to chemical exposures in multiple realms of their lives, from their jobs to their neighborhoods.

In the first case, this award facilitated an examination of “upstream” science -- foundational to but preceding policy and regulatory decisions about chemical safety and risk -- at the Environmental Protection Agency’s Office of Research and Development (EPA ORD). There, computational scientists are calibrating legacy information from toxicity testing on animals with large volumes of data being newly generated using protein- and cell- based chemical testing technologies. When paired with emerging models that predict the likelihood of exposure across larger numbers of chemicals than ever before, these techniques have the capacity to significantly enhance the Agency’s ability to prioritize chemicals for further assessment and possible regulatory action in a timely manner. These methods shift the scale and qualities of chemical evidence, and by doing so open political space for the contestation of what counts as an indicator of chemical harm and risk. Findings from this part of the project additionally suggest that, in their early instantiations, computational methods remain deeply tied to the traditional normative pathologies expressed in mammalian testing and struggle to characterize, with confidence, exposure experiences that differ significantly from median American exposures.

This award also facilitated the construction of a second ethnographic case analyzing how chemical harm is accounted for in disadvantaged neighborhoods south of downtown Phoenix where environmental justice activism dissipated after peaking in the 1990s. Residents of these communities live in zones of mixed industrial land use. Many of them have experience working with solvents, cleaning fluids, pesticides, and other common industrial and commercial substances. Under these conditions, ethnographic data demonstrate that chemicals and their effects register at intensities and timescales ranging from the suddenly and accurately injurious to the chronic and scarcely noticeable. Few people consider themselves environmental or social justice claimants. Factors beyond common barriers to mobilization such as resource scarcity are at play, including a certain aversion to anger valued by a subset of older community leaders. This research thus contributes empirical evidence from a negative case to environmental justice studies, advancing understandings of how and why people construct and act on grievances in a traditionally political manner (or not).

Taken as a whole, the ethnographic evidence from this project demonstrates that across even these radically different communities, chemical harm rarely materializes in a clear and spectacular way. Instead, findings from these cases highlight the continued importance of developing chemical science and governance methods that can better address issues of variability in susceptibility to chemical toxicity and exposure, and gradations and accumulations of harm and risk.  These insights are timely contributions to contemporary debates about how the federal government ought to account for chemicals’ potential to harm and leverage science to be heal...
